paper_abstract: Exact confidence intervals may be theoretically feasible for some problems but they can be difficult to obtain in practice as is often the case when there are nuisance parameters present. Consequently, likelihood-based interval estimation methods are often used in applied work. The loss in accuracy when approximate intervals are used is not necessarily a serious issue especially when we derive such intervals from O(n(-3/2)) accurate results like those in, for example, Fraser, D.A.S., Reid, N. and Wu, J., 1999, A simple general formula for tail probabilities for frequentist and bayesian inference. Biometrika, 86(2), 249-264. In this article, we obtain third-order accurate approximate confidence intervals for the location and scale parameters of the exponential inverse Gaussian distribution [Kanefuji, K. and Iwase, K., 1996, Exponential inverse Gaussian distribution. Computational Statistics, 11, 315-326.]. Results from a simulation study to compare these intervals with the first-order methods based on the asymptotic normality of maximum likelihood estimators and the signed log-likelihood ratio are presented. We also illustrate the interval estimation methods using four published datasets.
paper_title: Interval estimation for the exponential inverse Gaussian distribution
